headline: The Observer science quiz 2012: part 2
text: ROUND 2: IN THE NEWS 21. What happened this year but won't occur again until 2117? 22. The Libyan city of El Azizia was stripped of its 90-year record for being the hottest place on Earth after an investigation found an inexperienced stand-in probably misread a thermometer. The record passed to which location? 23. Sunita Williams became the second woman to command the International Space Station. Who was the first? 24. Which of Saturn's moons was featured on the 1.28 stamp from a Royal Mail set commemorating the 50th anniversary of the launch of Britain's first satellite? 25. A study found there had been a 10-fold increase in scientific research papers being retracted for what reason? 26. The emergence of a drug-resistant strain of which disease prompted a researcher to say: "It's like watching a slow-motion horror movie unfold"? 27. What did Ron Fouchier create that unleashed a security crisis in science? 28. According to a study published by the US National Cancer Institute, what can extend life expectancy by four years? 29. How long was the sentence of the scientists accused of underestimating the risks of the L'Aquila earthquake? 30. Francis Farley, 91, said of his novel Catalysed Fusion: "I was afraid people would be shocked by some of the sexy passages but they say it is reasonably tasteful  there are no four letter words in it. I think it is reasonably delicate." Where is the book set? 31. Who was appointed as the government's chief scientific adviser? 32. Which Russian established the most lucrative prize in science ever? 33. Cambridge scientists sequenced the whole genome of which superbug to stop an outbreak at a special care baby unit?  34. The failure to replicate what result meant that Professor Jim Al-Khalili did not have to eat his boxer shorts on live TV? 35. Shortly before he died, Apollo astronaut Neil Armstrong granted a rare interview to the certified practising accountants of which fortunate nation? 36. Who revealed POMC on chromosome2 to be his favourite gene?  37. Palaeontologists announced the discovery of Nyasasaurus parringtoni thought to be the world's oldest what? 38. What rule of nature was found to connect a 13th-century Italian mathematician and the human uterus? 39. Who announced a plan to email vaccines around the world? 40. Stephen Hawking, Martin Rees, Paul Nurse and eight other eminent signatories wrote to David Cameron asking for whom to be pardoned? ROUND 3: CURIOSITY 41. Nasa's Curiosity rover landed on Mars on 6 August. What was the distance of its journey from Earth? 42. How many times has Nasa landed onMars? 43. Name Curiosity's landing site. 44. The mission is expected to take oneMartian year. How many Earth weeks is this? 45. What is the fuel used in Curiosity's nuclear generator? 46. Curiosity weighs 899kg on Earth, how much does it weigh on Mars? 47. What major historical event happened on the same day 67 years before the touchdown of Curiosity? 48. How many "minutes of terror" were there between Curiosity entering Mars's atmosphere and touchdown? 49. The soil from Curiosity's first sample was described as being similar to the soil from which Pacific archipelago? 50. What kind of theories did the release of this self-portrait of Curiosity spark online? ROUND 4: WHO SAID? 51. Who said this about the Mariana Trench, seven miles under the Pacific: "It was a very, very soft, almost gelatinous flat plain, an almost featureless plain, that went out of sight as far as I could see." 52. Who said: "I know the whole world is watching right now and I wish the world could see what I can see." 53. Which broadcasting legend admitted: "Fifty years ago, I used to go along, chase a giant anteater and pull it by the tail so we could film it." 54. Which business mogul said: "Hopefully soon it should be possible to get Stephen Hawking into space." 55. Which politician gave a speech to a roomful of scientists at the Royal Society including this nugget? "No one can know what the future holds."  56. Which mathematical whizz said: "Numbers aren't perfect, but for me, it's numbers with all their imperfections versus bullshit." 57. Which theoretical physicist claimed: "I never expected this to happen in my lifetime and shall be asking my family to put some champagne in the fridge." 58. Which new member of the Commons Energy Committee once said: "Scientists would rather change facts than their theories."  59. Miley Cyrus was trashed by Christians for tweeting this quote: "Every atom in your body came from a star that exploded. And, the atoms in your left hand probably came from a different star than your right hand. It really is the most poetic thing I know about physics: You are all stardust. You couldn't be here if stars had not exploded, because the elements  the carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, iron, all the things that matter for evolution and for life  weren't created at the beginning of time. They were created in the nuclear furnaces of stars, and the only way for them to get into your body is if those stars were kind enough to explode. So forget Jesus; the stars died so that you could live." Which physicist is the author? 60. Who, at the opening of the London Paralympics, urged us to: "Look up at the stars, and not down at your feet. Try to make sense of what you see, and wonder about what makes the universe exist. Be curious."
